text: Bought a Full Spectrum 18 x 24 machine 3-1/2 years ago at approx. $9,000. Had to replace laser 8 month later. ($600) 2-1/2 years old and Main processor and power supply failed. Called F.S. and got nothing. They had stopped making the main control board and offered NO assistance. Bought a new power supply and Main processor from Light Object and got machine back up and running. Quite different software to learn, but, now I prefer it. I CAN'T recommend F.S. for their customer service or warranty. Just had to replace an axis driver. Another $50 gone! Please do your OWN research!

text: It‚Äôs all about the time you spend sanding the hardwood...and sanding it correctly, and you my friend did NOT sand that wood correctly. You have to start the sanding process at about a 60 grit and work your way all the way to at least 320 or even finer. 60, 80, 120, 180, 220, 320...in that order. It‚Äôs a pain in the ass but if you want a hard wood like maple to look the way it‚Äôs should then that‚Äôs the way you gotta do it...otherwise leave it raw or lime wax it.

text:
nice review....when $ is no object....My advice for anyone is read reviews and watch a lot...a lot of videos. Then so you dont throw your $ in the ocean....buy a K40 laser. Ya i know, its chinese, its unsafe, etc, etc..... you dont have to be a rocket scientist with these....i bought one on amazon, did a tweek here and there. I use inkscape (free)....and scorchworks (free) to use this K40 laser, and it works great....dont have to deal with chinese software.... you learn alot, the cost is super minumum.... if you dont like it, or you get bored with it, sell it on craigslist for  $200....lesson learned.
sooooo. to wrap things up.....Couple years ago, i built my own. bigger and better c02 laser and still using free software. Cost me $1500 to make, and i have more than made up the cost to make it.....life treating me fine right now....retired. Learned off the K40, reading reviews, watching you-tube videos......then make your own.....cant tell you how many people have made their own.....a ton.

text:
Nice video. Wish you focused more on the higher end lasers but not really your target audience and not something you have in the shop. I wouldn't put boss anywhere near epilog. 
For general use CO2 lasers I would do a list like this:
- K40 + upgrades
- 50W ebay/ali chinese
- 80W ebay/ai chinese
- All in ones or what you call kickstarter lasers (including the more expensive dremel brand one)
- Branded chinese lasers with local support (boss, thunder, aeon etc)
- Finally top tier RF lasers (epilog, trotec, ULS etc)
There's plenty of specific machines that fall outside those categories. Like aeon having an 'all in one' style series and thunder laser having RF source lasers.

text: Well i debated whether or not to even take the time to learn sketchup and i finally did. I use it for plans to accompany my videos and for client pitches to give everyone a clear understanding of exactly what will be produced. Now that I‚Äôm somewhat proficient in sketchup, of course, they make the announcement that it will no longer be free in the near future, so it seems like Fusion will be the way to go. I‚Äôve heard a few folks plugging your new 360 course and since folks who get my plans won‚Äôt even be able to view the models for free, it‚Äôs looking like I‚Äôll be making the switch in the near future.

text:
Sketchup has never adapted to 3D printing and struggles with small objects. This has some work arounds but the program is basically for architectural design. Maintaining solid mesh and other objects is often difficult with Sketchup.
Fusion 360 isn't perfect either but it has so many builtin functions that most things seem to be possible. 
Blender has so many modes it's frustrating for 3D printing and engineering design. It's so hard to get into I gave up.
video: Is Fusion 360 worth learning over Sketchup?

text: Watching for the F-16 flybys really gives you an appreciation of how crazy sharp the eyesight of fighter pilots has to be, to spot and track threats. I know they have radar, but in a dogfight, tracking the other guy is still mostly done done by keeping their head on a swivel. And trying to discern which way he‚Äôs facing, whether that‚Äôs his canopy or a false one painted under the nose. Sometimes even watching for the movement of control surfaces to telegraph a roll or a turn.
